progressions.name: I–IV–V (Primary Triads)
progressions.notes: Common triadic basis also referenced by twelve-bar blues sources.

progressions.name: iii–vi–ii–V (Turnaround Variant)
progressions.notes: Variant cited with rhythm changes context: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhythm_changes

progressions.name: i–VII–VI–VII (Aeolian)
progressions.notes: Common Aeolian loop; aligns with natural minor harmony practice.

progressions.name: i–VI–III–VII (Natural Minor Pop)
progressions.notes: Subset of the minor circle shown in vi–ii–V–I references.

progressions.name: i–iv–V–i (Harmonic Minor Cadence)
progressions.notes: Common minor-key practice with raised leading tone dominant.

progressions.name: iv–i (Minor Plagal)
progressions.notes: Common plagal resolution in minor contexts.

progressions.name: I–V–IV–I (Classic Rock Cadence)
progressions.notes: Simple cadential loop common in rock writing.

progressions.name: I–vi–ii–V–I (Anatole Major)
progressions.notes: Anatole/turnaround family; see I VI II V references in turnaround and rhythm changes sources.

progressions.name: VI7–II7–V7–I (Secondary Dominant Chain)
progressions.notes: Derived from ragtime/rhythm changes dominant-chain practice.

progressions.name: ii–V–I–vi (Turnaround Resolution)
progressions.notes: Variation often used in standards and song endings.

progressions.name: Romanesca Extended (III–VII–i–V–III–VII–i–V–i)
progressions.notes: Source pattern quoted on Romanesca page: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanesca

progressions.name: Lament Bass (Chromatic Descent)
progressions.notes: Source concept: chromatic fourth in lament bass: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lament_bass

progressions.name: Baroque Circle with Sevenths
progressions.notes: Source context: Baroque circle with added sevenths: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circle_of_fifths

progressions.name: Bach Passacaglia Ground (BWV 582 Style)
progressions.notes: Source context: ostinato-ground construction in BWV 582: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passacaglia_and_Fugue_in_C_minor%2C_BWV_582

progressions.name: Bach Chaconne Opening Variant (i–i7–VI–iv–V)
progressions.notes: Source context: Bach Chaconne links to Andalusian-type opening variant: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andalusian_cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chaconne Ground Loop (Descending Tetrachord)
progressions.notes: Source concept: chaconne as repeated harmonic/ground-bass progression: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaconne

progressions.name: Bach Deceptive Cadence (V–VI in Minor)
progressions.notes: Source: Bach Prelude in F minor deceptive cadence example (V–VI): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Phrygian Half Cadence (iv6–V)
progressions.notes: Source definition and baroque context: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Cadential Core (iv6–V–i)
progressions.notes: Source: Phrygian half cadence iv6-V in minor: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Chaconne Ground (Minor Ostinato)
progressions.notes: Source concept: chaconne built on repeated short progression/ground: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaconne

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: ii6–V–I (PAC)
progressions.notes: Cadence type in common-practice style used in Bach chorales corpus (BWV chorale lists): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence ; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chorale_harmonisations_by_Johann_Sebastian_Bach

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: I6/4–V–I
progressions.notes: Cadential dominant approach in chorale-style phrase endings; Bach has extensive 4-part chorale output: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chorale_harmonisations_by_Johann_Sebastian_Bach

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: I–ii6–V (Half Cadence)
progressions.notes: Half-cadence class in tonal syntax, commonly used at internal phrase boundaries: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: I–ii6–V–vi (Deceptive)
progressions.notes: Deceptive cadence (V to vi / VI), with Bach mention in cadence entry (Wachet auf example): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: IV–I (Plagal)
progressions.notes: Plagal cadence class within common-practice cadence taxonomy: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: IV–I6/4–V–I
progressions.notes: Plagal-to-authentic compound close in chorale-style phrase design (Bach chorale corpus context): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chorale_harmonisations_by_Johann_Sebastian_Bach

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: iv–V–i (Minor Authentic)
progressions.notes: Minor-mode authentic cadence class in common-practice harmony: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: iv6–V–i (Phrygian)
progressions.notes: Phrygian half cadence definition and usage in tonal practice: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: iv–V–I (Picardy Close)
progressions.notes: Picardy-third close often found in Bach minor chorales: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Picardy_third

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: I–vi–ii–V–I (Phrase Loop)
progressions.notes: Descending-fifths phrase archetype tied to circle-of-fifths syntax in Baroque writing: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circle_of_fifths

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: I–vii°6–I6–V–I
progressions.notes: Chorale-style passing diminished sonority in functional phrase-leading; 4-part chorale corpus context: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chorale_harmonisations_by_Johann_Sebastian_Bach

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: I–IV–V7–I
progressions.notes: Simple chorale-compatible phrase ending with dominant seventh and authentic close: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence

progressions.name: Bach Chorale Template: V–vi / V–I Pair
progressions.notes: Based on cadence-entry discussion of deceptive-to-authentic phrase parallel in Bach chorale setting (Wachet auf): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadence
